resource.name: 2015 Traffic Safety Survey
resource.description:
In April/May 2015, Strathcona County asked County residents to provide feedback about aspects of traffic safety in the community.  All quantitative survey results are available in this data set.

Information on the methodology used in the development and implementation of the survey can be found in the report 2015 Traffic Safety Survey Part One: Quantitative Research Results.

Results from open-ended survey questions are available in a companion report: 2015 Traffic Safety Survey Part Two: Qualitative Research Results. 

Both reports and the survey questions are attached (see About tab).
columns_name: Who would be contacted to address concerns about traffic safety?
I believe that Strathcona County is always working to improve road safety.
I believe that there is not enough traffic enforcement in Strathcona County.
I believe that Strathcona County engages its residents in addressing traffic safety.
I believe that red light cameras make intersections safer.
Do you drive a motor vehicle in Strathcona County?
Under ideal road conditions, how fast do you think it’s safe to drive on a main road in the County, such as Baseline Road or a rural grid road?
How acceptable do you think it is for a driver to talk on a cell phone while driving?
How acceptable do you think it is to roll through a stop sign?
How acceptable do you think it is to run a red light?
How acceptable do you think it is to drive over the speed limit on a residential street?
Are there any children under 18 years old in your household?
I believe that traffic enforcement in Strathcona County makes our roads safer.

Traffic Calming is the use of physical measures (curb extensions, speed humps) to reduce the undesirable effects of traffic in residential areas. To what extent do you agree with the statement? I support the use of traffic calming in Strathcona County.

Over the last year, Strathcona County has published a series of “Safe Travels” advertisements in the Sherwood Park News to inform residents about the safe system approach to traffic safety.  Did you notice these ads?
Did any of the information contained in these ads cause you to change your driving behaviour?
Did any of the information contained in these ads change the way you think about traffic safety?
To what extent do you agree or disagree that traffic safety is a concern in my neighbourhood?
Which of the following best describes what someone should do when driving in a construction zone?
How acceptable do you think it is to speed up to get through a yellow light?
How should residential speeding concerns be addressed?
Top 2 actions to improve traffic safety
Overall, how would you rate the state of traffic safety in Strathcona County?
How often do you come to a complete stop at stop signs?

resource.name: Notice of Awarded Contracts
resource.description: The Notice of Awarded Contracts program (NAC) is part of Strathcona County's ongoing commitment to open and transparent procurement practices, as stated in the Procurement Policy.  Through this initiative, awarded contracts of any value, for construction, services and goods; as well as purchase orders with a value of $50,000 or more, are posted monthly on the Open Data Portal.  For a definition of the Procurement processes identified see the Attachment under the About tab.
columns_description: The public procurement file number or the PO number issued to the vendor.

Services equals 51% or greater of the value of the contract is attributed to the provision of services.  Goods equals 51% or greater of the value of the contract is attributed to the purchase of goods.
Opportunities that follow a public process were posted to the Alberta Purchasing Connection website.

Consists of the aggregate value of the acquisition not including options or potential contract renewal or extension periods.  In the event that the award is based on unit rates including hourly charge out rates those values will not be posted due to confidentiality.  Field may be left blank in these instances.
Description of the acquisition and contract term if applicable.
The date the letter of intent, notification or award, or purchase order was issued.
See Procurement Process Definitions document in Attachments under the About Tab.

resource.name: 2015 Municipal Census - Enumeration Areas
resource.description:
Table representing household census data aggregated to Enumeration Area (EA) gathered in the 2015 Municipal Census.  
The municipal census was conducted in the spring of 2015. The census gathers information such as the number of people who live in the home, their ages and gender; the type of dwelling; and length of residency in Strathcona County. An up-to-date census count ensures the County receives the maximum grant dollars based on population. These dollars go toward municipal programs such as roads, transit, and community and family services. Census information is also used to plan for future services and programs.
The GIS Branch may use the household data for analysis; however, areas containing less than 50 people will not be reported. This practice is in line with Statistics Canada reporting. The data is not available directly to Strathcona County staff but is available upon request and permission from LLS. The data is not shared publicly at the household level.
For mapping purposes, this table can be joined by EA number to the polygon data set (https://data.strathcona.ca/Demographics/Municipal-Census-2015-EA/ns2u-t8q8).  Additionally, the centroid (point) of the EA polygon is included.

resource.name: 2011 National Household Survey (NHS) - Income by Census Tracts, Dissemination Areas, Wards and Urban Service Areas
resource.description:
The data shows income frequency distribution for individuals and households in four different boundary types. The data was provided by Statistics Canada but it has been sectioned and transposed. The fields come from NHS profile reports of Statistics Canada and some information may not be available for all the boundaries. The fields have been arranged in the same order as NHS profile reports. To see a more complete description of the fields click on this link: http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/nhs-enm/2011/dp-pd/prof/details/Page.cfm?Lang=E&Geo1=CSD&Code1=4811052&Data=Count&SearchText=Strathcona%20County&SearchType=Begins&SearchPR=01&A1=All&B1=All&GeoLevel=PR&GeoCode=10#tabs1
The field “Household income in 2010 of private households” in the Income of Households in 2010 section is not included in the data to avoid redundancy.

resource.name: Intermunicipal Development Plan/Joint Planning Study
resource.description:
An intermunicipal development plan (IDP) is a high-level statutory plan jointly developed by two or more neighbouring municipalities, and where at least one member is not part of a growth management region. An IDP ensures that land use decisions are coordinated between municipalities.

Recent changes to the Municipal Government Act (MGA) require that all municipalities within the province of Alberta with a shared boundary must complete and adopt an IDP, unless both municipalities are part of a growth region or have a mutual agreement for an IDP exemption. Strathcona County is part of the Edmonton Metropolitan Regional Board with the following municipalities, meaning IDPs are not required: the City of Edmonton, the City of Fort Saskatchewan, Leduc County, and Sturgeon County. 

A joint planning study is a document that facilitates collaboration and guides the development of strategies and tools to address emerging topics between two municipalities.

resource.name: Flower Beds
resource.description: Outdoor areas of land covered in flowers and serves to provide a pleasing aesthetic

resource.name: Habitat Priority Units
resource.description:
This data represents natural features and wildlife habitat in Strathcona County.

The Prioritized Landscape Ecology Assessment (PLEA) project was a joint effort between Strathcona County and Ducks Unlimited Canada. The main objective of the study was to complete a comprehensive identification of prioritized natural features and wildlife habitats across Strathcona County. The need for this study was driven by the conservation easement program being initiated within Strathcona County in 1996. https://www.strathcona.ca/council-county/plans-and-reports/strategic-documents/environmental-framework/plea/. The data is accurate to 1997

resource.name: Playgrounds
resource.description: “Playgrounds" are areas of land covered in a resilient surface containing play equipment designed to facilitate general recreation that are owned or operated by Strathcona County. These areas are commonly sand or rubber covered areas surrounded by one or more concreate retaining walls with swings, slides, decks, forts and other similar equipment. The bounds of the playground area are designated by Strathcona County and are always within a 'Park'.  Playgrounds can be located indoor or outdoor.  This data set includes traditional sand-covered playgrounds and creative playgrounds.  It does not included are facilities like BMX parks, parks, or splash parks.

resource.name: Playing Field
resource.description: “Playing Fields" are outdoor areas of land covered in grass and/or loose shale designed to facilitate organized and unorganized recreation that are owned or maintained by Strathcona County. These areas are commonly sport fields with designated boundaries for particular activities (i.e. soccer field) but can also allow general recreation and may not have specific visible boundaries on-site. It includes the bounds of the area as designated by Strathcona County and are always within a 'Park'. These typically include soccer field, football fields and baseball diamonds. Similar items excluded include Basketball Courts and outdoor rinks.

resource.name: Community Connection Grants (2016-2022)
resource.description:
The “Community Connection Grants Data” dataset lists grants awarded to Strathcona County Community Connection grant recipients from years 2016 – 2022. Grant recipients use the funds to supplement the cost of a community gathering (e.g. neighbourhood block party or outdoor movie night).

Sort the data by year, neighbourhood, activity (descriptor) and/or grant amount. Any event held outside hamlet boundaries is listed as Rural.

Please note, this data may vary slightly from the summary posted on the Community Grants webpage due a lag in data collection or event cancellation.

resource.name: 2018 Municipal Census - Enumeration Areas Map
resource.description:
Polygon areas representing household census data aggregated to enumeration area gathered in the 2018 Municipal Census. 
The municipal census was conducted in the spring of 2018. The census gathers information such as the number of people who live in the home, their ages and gender; the type of dwelling; and length of residency in Strathcona County. An up-to-date census count ensures the County receives the maximum grant dollars based on population. These dollars go toward municipal programs such as roads, transit, and community and family services. Census information is also used to plan for future services and programs. 
The GIS Branch may use the household data for analysis; however, areas containing less than 50 people will not be reported. This practice is in line with Statistics Canada reporting. The data is not available directly to Strathcona County staff but is available upon request and permission from LLS. The data is not shared publicly at the household level.

resource.name: Splash Parks
resource.description: “Splash Parks" are outdoor areas designated for water recreation that are owned by Strathcona County. Typically, a splash park (also referred to as a spray park) is a concrete area with water pipes, jets, colourful characters, and other items that move water by shooting, spraying, trickling, or other similar means. They are typically focused for children but all residents are welcome.  Splash parks are usually within a 'park' but not always.  This data set does not include areas like outdoor swimming pools, or water recreation features that people do not interact with such as decorative fountains.  Splash park features are represented as points.

resource.name: 2016 Priority Based Budgeting Programs
resource.description:
As part of the Priority Based Budgeting methodology, Strathcona County has identified 315 unique business programs that describe the services provided to the public. These defined programs are prioritized through a corporate evaluation, which influences the funding allocation.

As Strathcona County continues to implement priority based budgeting, programs and program descriptions will be continually looked at for refinements and improvements to best reflect the services that departments provides, both externally (to residents) and internally (to the organization).

resource.name: Priority Environment Management Units
resource.description:
This data represents Priority Environment Management Areas within Strathcona County. This data is intended to be used with Land Use planning.

Strathcona County supports cooperative efforts to ensure the quality of water, land, air and natural resources found within the region are maintained and enhanced. Priority environment management areas (PEMA) have been identified to aid the County in meeting the environment management objectives. The data displays buffers that have been created to protect lands and water resources as well as unique habitats. Data is static. It was collected around 2007 for the MDP report that year.

resource.name: 2018 Municipal Census - Enumeration Areas
resource.description:
Table representing household census data aggregated to Enumeration Area (EA) gathered in the 2018 Municipal Census. 
The municipal census was conducted in the spring of 2018. The census gathers information such as the number of people who live in the home, their ages and gender; the type of dwelling; and length of residency in Strathcona County. An up-to-date census count ensures the County receives the maximum grant dollars based on population. These dollars go toward municipal programs such as roads, transit, and community and family services. Census information is also used to plan for future services and programs.
The GIS Branch may use the household data for analysis; however, areas containing less than 50 people will not be reported. This practice is in line with Statistics Canada reporting. The data is not available directly to Strathcona County staff but is available upon request and permission from LLS. The data is not shared publicly at the household level.

resource.name: Outdoor Rinks
resource.description: “Outdoor Rinks" are outdoor areas of land designed to facilitate skating activities in the winter and general recreation in other seasons that are owned or maintained by Strathcona County. These areas are outdoor rinks but may not have permanent walls and/or can also allow general recreation. It includes the bounds of the area as designated by Strathcona County and are always within a 'Park'. These include permanent rinks and seasonal rinks (on grass or ice).
